metadata.h1: Problems with PER in the NBA
metadata.description: PER is an all-in-one statistic developed by John Hollinger. John currently writes for The Athletic, was the VP of Basketball Operations for the Memphis Grizzlies, and was a columnist at ESPN and…

all_paragraphs: If you’re a fan of NBA basketball and you’re a fan of analytics, you’ve heard of PER.

PER is an all-in-one statistic developed by John Hollinger. John currently writes for The Athletic, was the VP of Basketball Operations for the Memphis Grizzlies, and was a columnist at ESPN and Sports Illustrated. He is the author of four basketball analytics books and is a titan of the NBA analytics community.
The player efficiency rating (PER) is a rating of a player’s per-minute productivity.

PER is rightly cited as one of the godfather stats of the advanced analytics movement in basketball. It was one of the first basketball measurements to adjust for pace of play, adjust for playing time, and to normalize data across seasons (the measure assigns an average player for each season at 15 PER). PER is still commonly cited on broadcasts and in the media.
Some people say PER is overly complex. Some say it doesn’t account enough for defense. Others say it overvalues scoring.

While the above statements may be true, the real problem lies in the methodology — it’s less about the math and more about the approach to data analysis that led to its imperfections. Today, I want to focus on Hollinger’s PER research method in hopes that we can all — as data scientists — avoid similar mistakes in the future.
In research there are a few general steps scientists follow:
Now that we have a basic understanding of research methods, let’s take a brief theoretical look at how you might approach figuring out per-minute productivity in the NBA.
Let’s compare this to what we see with John Hollinger’s work with PER.

What PER can do, however, is summarize a player’s statistical accomplishments in a single number. That allows us to unify the disparate data on each player we try to track in our heads[…] so that we can move on to evaluating what might be missing from the stats.
He achieved the former goal with PER, but along the way he failed to conduct the basic scientific analysis needed to make sure his metric was statistically valid in achieving the latter.

To be fair to John Hollinger, he might not consider himself a data scientist. Heck, he probably thought PER would primarily be a tool for him to use for his writing, and he’s probably updated his personal beliefs on PER.

But the work he did with PER definitely falls under the data science scope, and PER hasn’t been updated as a statistical measure. There were some mistakes he could have easily avoided with PER if he’d followed basic scientific method principles from the beginning.
Additionally — because PER is so popular — many other data scientists in the basketball analytics community are also making the same mistakes Hollinger made.
Let’s try and put a stop to that. Here is how you can easily learn from (and avoid) the data science mistakes made with PER.
In data analysis it’s extremely important to be specific in all aspects of your project. Make sure you:
If you don’t do this before you start extracting data you’re basically running blind and wasting a lot of time.

If John Hollinger had been more specific with his PER methodology we would easily be able to see whether or not PER was an effective measure. As it stands, we don’t know what “productivity” is in the context of PER according to John. We all have our own ideas — mine is that productivity should be measured by team wins — but it’s all based on our personal definitions instead of a stated definition by the scientist conducting the research.

This ties into the former point — since Hollinger had no specific outcome variables there are no reported findings. Websites that still use PER do not report whether PER significantly predicts wins, what percentage of wins it predicts, or any other findings regarding potential outcome variables.
For any project you do, it’s imperative that you report both the significance and effect size of your independent (i.e. predictor) variables on any dependent measures you’re interested in.

The PER on the ESPN and Basketball-Reference.com websites remain the same — the metric hasn’t changed since its inception. If you are going to do data science, you have to be ready to iterate based on your findings.

Just because you had beliefs about something before doesn’t mean you shouldn’t update those beliefs if you find evidence that runs to the contrary. Let the data guide you to better theories and models.
Despite its flaws PER remains a heavily used NBA statistics. Why is that?

Well, for one, I’m quite certain it does predict some amount of variance in team wins (even if the effect sizes haven’t been stated outright). There’s also the matter of cultural relevance — PER is embedded deeply into NBA culture now.
It’s cultural relevance comes down to two main things:

15 — the “average” PER score — is a relatable basketball score. If someone scores 15 “real” points in a basketball game we think of them as a good player. If someone scores in the high 20s or in the 30s we see them as a great player.
In that sense, PER is brilliant. John Hollinger understood the psychology of NBA fans and made sure his measurement was something his readers could easily identify with.

Again, PER is not a perfect measure. But by including it in your research we can get a better understanding of its effectiveness as a metric — something that is currently lacking due to the problems we’ve mentioned above. You’ll also be able to compare the efficacy of other metrics compared to PER, giving us a baseline of metric efficiency.
The only way to cure the problems we have with PER are to actually observe PER in data science settings — even if we don’t find it to be the metric we rely on.

Just like George Mikan shouldn’t be considered the greatest basketball player of all time, we shouldn’t consider PER the GOAT of basketball analytics. Smart teams seemed to have moved on from using it as a measure of player evaluation. Hopefully, broadcasters and media members will move away from it too as we get more knowledgeable about how the game of basketball should be measured statistically.
At the same time, PER is the cultural keystone of basketball analytics. I’m not joking when I say I think it should be enshrined in the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame.
It might fail some simple scientific principles, but without it we might still be stuck in the dark ages of basketball statistics.
As data scientists, we should revere what John Hollinger did — and then learn to do better.
